items.author: Lisa Schwarzbaum
items.content: Ah, monsieur, you can lead a Frenchman to the Big Apple, but you can't make him a New Yorker -- and that's exactly what makes The Professional so fascinating.

items.author: Hal Hinson
items.content: Oldman is the least inhibited actor of his generation, and as this deranged detective, he keeps absolutely nothing in reserve.

items.author: The A.V. Club
items.content: Few action films can claim such complexities without conceding the bang-bang stuff that brings in the big money.

items.author: Marc Savlov
items.content: Besson's visuals are, as always, vibrant and decidedly European. He fills the frames with odd-angled shots and alarming riots of color that catch you off-balance.

items.author: James Berardinelli
items.content: With some surprisingly strong character interaction, there's a lot to like about this movie, at least for those willing to look beyond all the bloodshed.

items.author: Richard Schickel
items.content: This is a Cuisinart of a movie, mixing familiar yet disparate ingredients, making something odd, possibly distasteful, undeniably arresting out of them. [5 Dec 1994, p. 93]

items.author: Roger Ebert
items.content: Besson has a natural gift for plunging into drama with a charged-up visual style.
Takes its viewers on a bouncing high-wire act between intense violence and sugar-sweet tenderness, with some light-hearted comedy along the way.

items.author: Jonathan Rosenbaum
items.content: The sheer oddness of the New York world constructed for this film--where cops and crooks are literally interchangeable, and Oldman and Danny Aiello are stranded in roles that pick over the leavings of earlier parts--ultimately seems at once too deranged and too mechanical.

items.author: Janet Maslin
items.content: Lacks the sexy elan of "La Femme Nikita" and suffers from infinitely worse culture shock. [18 Nov 1994, p.C18]
